<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->-3-<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>


<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif">
<!-- xbrl,ns -->
<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>AMERICAN AIRLINES, INC CORPORATION</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left">
<A name="106"></A>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 0pt"><B>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS</B><BR>
<U>(Unaudited)</U>

</DIV>

<!-- xbrl,n -->
<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt">
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left">1.<DIV style="display: none">&nbsp;Basis of Presentation</DIV></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>
<!-- xbrl,body -->

<DIV style="text-align: justify">The accompanying unaudited condensed consolidated financial statements have been prepared in
accordance with United States (U.S.) generally accepted accounting principles for interim
financial information and with the instructions to Form 10-Q and Article&nbsp;10 of Regulation&nbsp;S-X.
Accordingly, they do not include all of the information and footnotes required by generally
accepted accounting principles for complete financial statements. In the opinion of
management, these financial statements contain all adjustments, consisting of normal recurring
accruals, necessary to present fairly the financial position, results of operations and cash
flows for the periods indicated. Results of operations for the periods presented herein are
not necessarily indicative of results of operations for the entire year. American Airlines,
Inc. (American or the Company) is a wholly owned subsidiary of AMR Corporation (AMR). The
condensed consolidated financial statements also include the accounts of variable interest
entities for which the Company is the primary beneficiary. For further information, refer to
the consolidated financial statements and footnotes included in the American Airlines, Inc.
Annual Report on Form 10-K filed on February&nbsp;17, 2010 (the 2009 Form 10-K).</DIV></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
</DIV>

<!-- xbrl,n -->
<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt">
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left">2.<DIV style="display: none">&nbsp;Commitments and Contingencies</DIV></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>
<!-- xbrl,body -->
<DIV style="text-align: justify">As of June&nbsp;30, 2010, American had 24 Boeing 737-800 aircraft purchase commitments for the
remainder of 2010 and eight Boeing 737-800 aircraft purchase commitments in 2011. In addition
to these aircraft purchase commitments, American had firm commitments for eleven Boeing
737-800 aircraft and seven Boeing 777 aircraft scheduled to be delivered in 2013 through 2016.
In addition, American previously announced plans (subject to certain reconfirmation rights)
to acquire 42 Boeing 787-9 aircraft, with the right to acquire an additional 58 Boeing 787-9
aircraft. American has selected GE Aviation as the exclusive provider of engines for its
expected order of Boeing 787-9 aircraft.</DIV></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt">
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD><DIV style="text-align: justify">As of June&nbsp;30, 2010, payments for the above purchase commitments will approximate $658&nbsp;million
in the remainder of 2010, $348&nbsp;million in 2011, $217&nbsp;million in 2012, $463&nbsp;million in 2013, $224
million in 2014, and $246&nbsp;million for 2015 and beyond. These amounts are net of purchase
deposits currently held by the manufacturers.</DIV></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt">
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD><DIV style="text-align: justify">The Company&#146;s future long-term debt and operating lease payments have changed as its ordered
aircraft are delivered and such deliveries have been financed. As of June&nbsp;30, 2010, maturities
of long-term debt (including sinking fund requirements) for the next five years are: remainder
of 2010 &#150; $517&nbsp;million, 2011 &#150; $2.1&nbsp;billion, 2012
&#150; $1.5&nbsp;billion, 2013 &#150; $717&nbsp;million, and
2014 &#150; $1.2&nbsp;billion. Future minimum lease payments required under operating leases that have
initial or remaining non-cancelable lease terms in excess of a year as of June&nbsp;30, 2010, were (in
millions): remainder of 2010 &#150; $493&nbsp;million, 2011 &#150;
$1.1&nbsp;billion, 2012 &#150; $896&nbsp;million, 2013
 &#150; $803&nbsp;million, 2014 &#150; $664&nbsp;million, and 2015
and beyond &#150; $5.5&nbsp;billion.</DIV></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt">
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD><DIV style="text-align: justify">The Company is in active labor contract negotiations with each of its organized labor groups.
The Company has negotiated tentative agreements with several workgroups within the Transport
Workers Union of America, AFL-CIO (TWU)&nbsp;including the Maintenance Control Technician group, the
Material Logistics Specialists group and the Mechanic and Related group. Agreements with these
TWU groups are subject to ratification by the relevant membership of TWU, and there are no
assurances that these tentative agreements will be ratified. These tentative agreements include
lump sum payments and contractual salary increases. If these contracts are ratified by union
membership during the third quarter of 2010, the Company will incur approximately $60&nbsp;million
for lump sum payments and contractual salary increases in that period. The Company anticipates
implementing productivity improvements consistent with the agreements that will help to offset
the ongoing cost of salary increases.</DIV></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt">
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD><DIV style="text-align: justify">On December&nbsp;18, 2007, the European Commission issued a Statement of Objection (SO)&nbsp;against 26
airlines, including the Company. The SO alleges that these carriers participated in a
conspiracy to set surcharges on cargo shipments in violation of European Union (EU)&nbsp;law. The SO
states that, in the event that the allegations in the SO are affirmed, the Commission will
impose fines against the Company. The Company intends to vigorously contest the allegations and
findings in the SO under EU laws, and it intends to cooperate fully with all other pending
investigations. Based on the information to date, the Company has not recorded any reserve for
this exposure as of June&nbsp;30, 2010. In the event that the SO is affirmed or other investigations
indicate violations of the U.S. antitrust laws or the competition laws of some other
jurisdiction, or if the Company were named and found liable in any litigation based on these
allegations, such findings and related legal proceedings could have a material adverse impact on
the Company.</DIV></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
</DIV>
<!-- xbrl,ig -->
<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->-4-<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<!-- xbrl -->

<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif">


<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt"><TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">
</TABLE>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>AMERICAN AIRLINES, INC CORPORATION<BR>
NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS</B><BR>
<U>(Unaudited)</U>

</DIV>
<!-- /xbrl,ig -->
<!-- xbrl,n -->
<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt">
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left">3.<DIV style="display: none">&nbsp;Depreciation and Amortization</DIV></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>
<!-- xbrl,body -->
<DIV style="text-align: justify">Accumulated depreciation of owned equipment and property at June&nbsp;30, 2010 and December&nbsp;31,
2009 was $9.5&nbsp;billion and $9.2&nbsp;billion, respectively. Accumulated amortization of equipment
and property under capital leases at June&nbsp;30, 2010 and December&nbsp;31, 2009 was $555&nbsp;million and
$571&nbsp;million, respectively.</DIV></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
</DIV>

<!-- xbrl,n -->
<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt">
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left">4.<DIV style="display: none">&nbsp;Valuation Allowance</DIV></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>
<!-- xbrl,body -->
<DIV style="text-align: justify">As discussed in Note 8 to the consolidated financial statements in the 2009 Form 10-K, the
Company has a valuation allowance against the full amount of its net deferred tax asset. The
Company currently provides a valuation allowance against deferred tax assets when it is more
likely than not that some portion, or all of its deferred tax assets, will not be realized.
The Company&#146;s deferred tax asset valuation allowance increased approximately $146&nbsp;million
during the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2010 to $3.7&nbsp;billion as of June&nbsp;30, 2010, including the
impact of comprehensive income for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2010 and changes from other
adjustments.</DIV></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD><DIV style="text-align: justify">Under current accounting rules, the Company is required to consider all items (including items
recorded in other comprehensive income) in determining the amount of tax benefit that results
from a loss from continuing operations and that should be allocated to continuing operations.
As a result, the Company recorded a tax benefit on the loss from continuing operations in 2009,
which was exactly offset by income tax expense on other comprehensive income. The Company
generally does not record any such tax benefit allocation in interim reporting periods as the
Company concluded the potential benefit is not considered realizable because the change in the
pension liability, a material component of other comprehensive income, is determined annually.
Thus, any such interim tax benefit allocation may subsequently be subject to reversal.</DIV></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
</DIV>

<!-- xbrl,n -->
<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt">
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left">5.<DIV style="display: none">&nbsp;Guarantees</DIV></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>
<!-- xbrl,body -->
<DIV style="text-align: justify">As of June&nbsp;30, 2010, American had issued guarantees covering approximately $887&nbsp;million of
AMR&#146;s unsecured debt (and interest thereon). In addition, as of June&nbsp;30, 2010, AMR and
American had issued guarantees covering approximately $239&nbsp;million of AMR Eagle&#146;s secured debt
(and interest thereon).</DIV></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
</DIV>

<!-- xbrl,n -->
<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt">
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left">6.<DIV style="display: none">&nbsp;Fair Value Disclosures</DIV></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>
<!-- xbrl,body -->
<DIV style="text-align: justify">The Company utilizes the market approach to measure fair value for its financial assets and
liabilities. The market approach uses prices and other relevant information generated by
market transactions involving identical or comparable assets or liabilities. The Company&#146;s
short-term investments classified as Level 2 primarily utilize broker quotes in a non-active
market for valuation of these securities. The Company&#146;s fuel derivative contracts, which
consist of commodity options and collars, are valued using energy and commodity market data
which is derived by combining raw inputs with quantitative models and processes to generate
forward curves and volatilities. No changes in valuation techniques or inputs occurred during
the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2010.</DIV></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD><DIV style="text-align: justify">Financial assets and liabilities measured at fair value on a recurring basis are summarized
below:</DIV></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
</DIV>

<!-- xbrl -->

<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif">


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>AMERICAN AIRLINES, INC.<BR>
NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (CONTINUED)</B><BR>
<U>(Unaudited)</U>

</DIV>


<DIV style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">
<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="92"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="left"><SUP style="FONT-size: 85%; vertical-align: text-top">1</SUP></TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD><DIV style="text-align: justify">Unrealized gains or losses on short-term investments, restricted cash and
short-term investments and derivatives qualifying for hedge accounting are recorded in
Accumulated other comprehensive income (loss) (OCI)&nbsp;at each measurement date.</DIV></TD>
</TR>

<TR style="font-size: 3pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="left"><SUP style="FONT-size: 85%; vertical-align: text-top">2</SUP></TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD><DIV style="text-align: justify">The majority of the Company&#146;s short-term investments mature in one year or less
except for $877&nbsp;million of Short term obligations and $232&nbsp;million of U.S. government agency
notes which have maturity dates exceeding one year.</DIV></TD>
</TR>

</table>

<DIV style="font-size: 3pt">&nbsp;</DIV>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">
<TR>
    <TD width="2%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="96"></TD>
</TR>


<TR valign="top">

    <TD nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD><DIV style="text-align: justify">No significant transfers between Level 1 and Level 2 occurred during the six months ended June
30, 2010. The Company&#146;s policy regarding the recording of transfers between levels is to record
any such transfers at the end of the reporting period.</DIV></TD>
</TR>

<TR style="font-size: 3pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD><DIV style="text-align: justify">In January&nbsp;2010, the Venezuelan Government devalued its currency from 2.15 bolivars per U.S.
dollar to 4.30 bolivars per U.S. dollar and the Venezuelan economy was designated as highly
inflationary. As a result, the Company recognized a loss of $53&nbsp;million related to the currency
remeasurement in January&nbsp;2010. The Company does not expect any significant ongoing impact of
the currency devaluation on its system-wide operations.</DIV></TD>
</TR>

<TR style="font-size: 3pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD><DIV style="text-align: justify">The fair values of the Company&#146;s long-term debt were estimated using quoted market prices where
available. For long-term debt not actively traded, fair values were estimated using discounted
cash flow analyses, based on the Company&#146;s current estimated incremental borrowing rates for
similar types of borrowing arrangements.</DIV></TD>
</TR>

<TR style="font-size: 12pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD><DIV style="text-align: justify">The carrying value and estimated fair values of the Company&#146;s long-term debt, including current
maturities, were (in millions):</DIV></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>


<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt">
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD><DIV style="text-align: justify">The Company is required to make minimum contributions to its defined benefit pension plans under
the minimum funding requirements of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA), the
Pension Funding Equity Act of 2004 and the Pension Protection Act of 2006. On June&nbsp;25, 2010,
President Obama signed the Preservation of Access to Care for Medical Beneficiaries and Pension
Relief Act of 2010 (the Relief Act), H.R. 3962, into law. The Relief Act provides for
temporary, targeted funding relief (subject to certain terms and conditions) for single employer
and multiemployer pension plans that suffered significant losses in asset value due to the steep
market slide in 2008. Under the Relief Act, the Company&#146;s 2010 minimum required contributions
to its defined benefit pension plans have been reduced from $525&nbsp;million to approximately $460
million. On July&nbsp;15, 2010, the Company contributed an additional $72&nbsp;million to its defined
benefit pension plans, for a total of $144&nbsp;million in 2010 as of the date of this filing.</DIV></TD>
</TR>

<!-- xbrl,n -->
<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left">8.<DIV style="display: none">&nbsp;Special Charges and Restructuring Activities</DIV></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>
<!-- xbrl,body -->
<DIV style="text-align: justify">As a result of the revenue environment, high fuel prices and the Company&#146;s restructuring
activities, including its capacity reductions, the Company has recorded a number of charges
during the last few years. In 2008 and 2009, the Company announced capacity reductions due to
unprecedented high fuel costs at that time and the other challenges facing the industry. In
connection with these capacity reductions, the Company incurred special charges related to
aircraft and certain other charges.</DIV></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
</DIV>
<!-- xbrl,ig -->
<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->-7-<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt">
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD><DIV style="text-align: justify">Cash outlays related to the accruals for aircraft charges and facility exit costs will occur
through 2017 and 2018, respectively.</DIV></TD>
</TR>

<!-- xbrl,n -->
<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left">9.<DIV style="display: none">&nbsp;Derivative and Financial Instruments</DIV></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>
<!-- xbrl,body -->
<DIV style="text-align: justify">As part of the Company&#146;s risk management program, it uses a variety of financial instruments,
primarily heating oil option and collar contracts, as cash flow hedges to mitigate commodity
price risk. The Company does not hold or issue derivative financial instruments for trading
purposes. As of June&nbsp;30, 2010, the Company had fuel derivative contracts outstanding covering
32&nbsp;million barrels of jet fuel that will be settled over the next 24&nbsp;months. A deterioration
of the Company&#146;s liquidity position may negatively affect the Company&#146;s ability to hedge fuel
in the future.</DIV></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD><DIV style="text-align: justify">For the three and six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2010, the Company recognized an increase of
approximately $58&nbsp;million and $103&nbsp;million, respectively, in fuel expense on the accompanying
consolidated statements of operations related to its fuel hedging agreements, including the
ineffective portion of the hedges. For the three and six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2009, the
Company recognized an increase of approximately $179&nbsp;million and $422&nbsp;million, respectively, in
fuel expense related to its fuel hedging agreements including the ineffective portion of the
hedges. The net fair value of the Company&#146;s fuel hedging agreements at June&nbsp;30, 2010 and
December&nbsp;31, 2009, representing the amount the Company would receive upon termination of the
agreements (net of settled contract assets), totaled $22&nbsp;million and $57&nbsp;million, respectively,
which excludes a payable related to contracts that settled in the last month of each respective
reporting period.</DIV></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD><DIV style="text-align: justify">The impact of cash flow hedges on the Company&#146;s consolidated financial statements is depicted
below (in millions):</DIV></TD>
</TR>

<TR style="font-size: 3pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD COLSPAN="3"><DIV style="text-align: justify">The Company is also exposed to credit losses in the event of non-performance by counterparties
to these financial instruments, and although no assurances can be given, the Company does not
expect any counterparty to fail to meet its obligations. The credit exposure related to these
financial instruments is represented by the fair value of contracts with a positive fair value
at the reporting date, reduced by the effects of master netting agreements. To manage credit
risks, the Company selects counterparties based on credit ratings, limits its exposure to a
single counterparty under defined guidelines, and monitors the market position of the program
and its relative market position with each counterparty. The Company also maintains
industry-standard security agreements with a number of its counterparties which may require the
Company or the counterparty to post collateral if the value of selected instruments exceeds
specified mark-to-market thresholds or upon certain changes in credit ratings.</DIV></TD>
</TR>

<TR style="font-size: 3pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD COLSPAN="3"><DIV style="text-align: justify">The Company includes changes in the fair value of certain derivative financial instruments that
qualify for hedge accounting and unrealized gains and losses on available-for-sale securities
in comprehensive income. For the three month periods ended June&nbsp;30, 2010 and 2009,
comprehensive gain (loss)&nbsp;was $(48) million and $101&nbsp;million, respectively, and for the six
month periods ended June&nbsp;30, 2010 and 2009, comprehensive loss was $(446) million and $(75)
million, respectively. The difference between net earnings (loss)&nbsp;and comprehensive income
(loss)&nbsp;for the three and six month periods ended June&nbsp;30, 2010 and 2009 is due primarily to the
accounting for the Company&#146;s derivative financial instruments and the actuarial loss on the
pension benefit obligation of the Company&#146;s pension plans.</DIV></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif">
<DIV align="left">
<A name="107"></A>
</DIV>

<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><U><B>Item&nbsp;2</B></U><B>. </B><U><B>Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations</B></U>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><U><B>Forward-Looking Information</B></U>

</DIV>

<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Statements in this report contain various forward-looking statements within the meaning of Section
27A of the Securities Act of 1933, as amended, and Section&nbsp;21E of the Securities Exchange Act of
1934, as amended, which represent the Company&#146;s expectations or beliefs concerning future events.
When used in this document and in documents incorporated herein by reference, the words &#147;expects,&#148;
&#147;plans,&#148; &#147;anticipates,&#148; &#147;indicates,&#148; &#147;believes,&#148; &#147;forecast,&#148; &#147;guidance,&#148; &#147;outlook,&#148; &#147;may,&#148; &#147;will,&#148;
&#147;should,&#148; &#147;seeks,&#148; &#147;targets&#148; and similar expressions are intended to identify forward-looking
statements. Similarly, statements that describe the Company&#146;s objectives, plans or goals, or
actions the Company may take in the future, are forward-looking statements. Forward-looking
statements include, without limitation, the Company&#146;s expectations concerning operations and
financial conditions, including changes in capacity, revenues, and costs; future financing plans
and needs; the amounts of its unencumbered assets and other sources of liquidity; fleet plans;
overall economic and industry conditions; plans and objectives for future operations; regulatory
approvals and actions, including the Company&#146;s applications for antitrust immunity with other
<B>one</B>world alliance members; and the impact on the Company of its results of operations in recent
years and the sufficiency of its financial resources to absorb that impact. In particular, this
report includes an estimate of revenue improvement and cost savings associated with certain Company
initiatives, a statement regarding when those benefits will be realized, and a statement regarding
the Company&#146;s expectations regarding the narrowing of its labor cost disadvantage, each of which is
a forward-looking statement. Guidance given in this report regarding capacity, fuel consumption,
fuel prices, fuel hedging, and unit costs, and statements regarding expectations of regulatory
approval of the Company&#146;s applications for antitrust immunity with other <B>one</B>world members are also
forward-looking statements. Other forward-looking statements include statements which do not
relate solely to historical facts, such as, without limitation, statements which discuss the
possible future effects of current known trends or uncertainties, or which indicate that the future
effects of known trends or uncertainties cannot be predicted, guaranteed or assured. All
forward-looking statements in this report are based upon information available to the Company on
the date of this report. The Company undertakes no obligation to publicly update or revise any
forward-looking statement, whether as a result of new information, future events, or otherwise.
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Forward-looking statements are subject to a number of factors that could cause the Company&#146;s actual
results to differ materially from the Company&#146;s expectations. The following factors could cause
the Company&#146;s actual results to differ materially from those expressed in forward-looking
statements: the materially weakened financial condition of the Company, resulting from its
significant losses in recent years; very weak demand for air travel and lower investment asset
returns resulting from the severe global economic downturn; the Company&#146;s need to raise substantial
additional funds and its ability to do so on acceptable terms; the ability of the Company to
generate additional revenues and reduce its costs; continued high and volatile fuel prices and
further increases in the price of fuel, and the availability of fuel; the Company&#146;s substantial
indebtedness and other obligations; the ability of the Company to satisfy certain covenants and
conditions in certain of its financing and other agreements; changes in economic and other
conditions beyond the Company&#146;s control, and the volatile results of the Company&#146;s operations; the
fiercely and increasingly competitive business environment faced by the Company; potential industry
consolidation and alliance changes; competition with reorganized carriers; low fare levels by
historical standards and the Company&#146;s reduced pricing power; changes in the Company&#146;s corporate or
business strategy; extensive government regulation of the Company&#146;s business; conflicts overseas or
terrorist attacks; uncertainties with respect to the Company&#146;s international operations; outbreaks
of a disease (such as SARS, avian flu or the H1N1 virus) that affects travel behavior; labor costs
that are higher than those of the Company&#146;s competitors; uncertainties with respect to the
Company&#146;s relationships with unionized and other employee work groups; increased insurance costs
and potential reductions of available insurance coverage; the Company&#146;s ability to retain key
management personnel; potential failures or disruptions of the Company&#146;s computer, communications
or other technology systems; losses and adverse publicity resulting from any accident involving the
Company&#146;s aircraft; interruptions or disruptions in service at one or more of the Company&#146;s primary
market airports; the heavy taxation of the airline industry; changes in the price of the Company&#146;s
common stock; and the ability of the Company to reach acceptable agreements with third parties.
Additional information concerning these and other factors is contained in the Company&#146;s Securities
and Exchange Commission filings, including the 2009 Form 10-K.
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->-10-<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif">




<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><U><B>Overview</B></U>
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The Company recorded a net loss of $7&nbsp;million in the second quarter of 2010 compared to a net loss
of $388&nbsp;million in the same period last year. The Company&#146;s improved performance is primarily the
result of higher unit revenues (passenger revenue per available seat mile). Mainline passenger
unit revenues increased 16.8&nbsp;percent for the second quarter due to a 2.0 point load factor increase
and a 14.0&nbsp;percent increase in passenger yield (passenger revenue per passenger mile) compared to
the same period in 2009. Although the Company recorded significant year-over-year unit revenue
improvement in the second quarter of 2010, passenger yields remain insufficient to drive positive
net earnings. The Company believes this is the result of a fragmented industry with numerous
competitors, excess capacity and pricing transparency resulting from the use of the Internet and
other factors. The Company believes that its limited pricing power could persist indefinitely.
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The increases in comparative second quarter revenue were partially offset by a significant
year-over-year increase in fuel prices from an average of $1.89 per gallon in the second quarter of
2009 to an average of $2.37 per gallon in the second quarter of 2010, including the effects of
hedging. The price increase resulted in $302&nbsp;million in incremental year-over-year fuel expense in
the three months ended June&nbsp;30, 2010 (based on the year-over-year increase in the average price per
gallon multiplied by gallons consumed).
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In addition, the Company&#146;s North Atlantic operations in the second quarter 2010 were impacted by
the eruption of the Icelandic volcano which began in April. However, flight disruptions did not
have a material adverse impact on the Company&#146;s results. Comparatively, during the second quarter
of 2009, there was an outbreak of the H1N1 Influenza virus which had an estimated $50 to $80
million adverse revenue impact, primarily on operations to and from Mexico. Also in the second
quarter 2009, the Company incurred approximately $70&nbsp;million in non-recurring charges related to
the sale of certain aircraft and the grounding of leased Airbus A300 aircraft prior to lease
expiration.
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In late
2009, the Company unveiled a new business plan &#150; FlightPlan 2020. FlightPlan 2020 is a
strategic framework developed to secure the Company&#146;s future by focusing on what will be required
to succeed in the airline business over the next decade. It establishes the Company&#146;s priorities
and a clear path to better position the Company to meet the challenges of the coming years. This
plan for achieving sustained profitability has five tenets: (i)&nbsp;Invest Wisely, (ii)&nbsp;Earn Customer
Loyalty, (iii)&nbsp;Strengthen and Defend our Global Network, (iv)&nbsp;Be a Good Place for Good People and
(v)&nbsp;Fly Profitably.
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Under FlightPlan 2020, the Company launched its network strategy that focuses resources in its
cornerstone markets of Dallas/Fort Worth, Chicago, Miami, Los Angeles and New York, and has
continued to execute its fleet renewal and replacement plan. Further, the Company continues to
pursue its strategy to form cooperative agreements with <B>one</B>world members and other airlines. On
July&nbsp;14, 2010 and July 20, 2010, American obtained clearance from the European Commission (EC)&nbsp;and
approval by the Department of Transportation (DOT), respectively, for antitrust immunity (ATI)&nbsp;for
its planned cooperation with British Airways, Iberia, Finnair and Royal Jordanian. In addition,
the Company is awaiting approval by regulatory entities of American&#146;s joint business agreement
(JBA)&nbsp;with Japan Airlines (JAL).
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Regulatory conditions for ATI approval for the British Airways, Iberia, Finnair and Royal Jordanian
cooperative agreement include obligations to lease to other carriers up to seven takeoff and landing slot pairs at
London Heathrow and up to three John F. Kennedy airport operational authorities, depending on
market conditions. In addition to satisfaction of those conditions, implementation of the JBA
requires successful negotiation of certain detailed financial and commercial arrangements among the carriers, and
obtaining other approvals. American expects to begin implementing the JBA in the fourth quarter of
2010. No assurances can be given as to any arrangements that may ultimately be implemented or any
benefits the Company may derive from such arrangements.
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The Company&#146;s and JAL&#146;s joint application to DOT for ATI on certain routes and joint notification
to the Ministry of Land Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism of Japan (MLIT)&nbsp;is pending approval.
Implementation of the JBA with JAL is also subject to successful negotiation of certain detailed
financial and commercial arrangements and other approvals. American expects to begin implementing
the JBA with JAL in 2011. No assurances can be given as to any arrangements that may
ultimately be implemented or any benefits that the Company may derive from such arrangements.
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->-11-<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif">




<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The Company&#146;s agreements for the previously announced commercial collaboration in New York and
Boston with JetBlue commenced on July&nbsp;20, 2010. The agreement provides customers with convenient,
interline service in non-overlapping markets, letting customers connect between 14 of American&#146;s
international destinations from New York&#146;s John F. Kennedy International Airport and Boston&#146;s Logan
Airport and 18 domestic cities flown from those two airports by JetBlue. Further, American
announced it will expand its relationship with JetBlue in the coming months, so that AAdvantage
members and members of JetBlue&#146;s customer loyalty program will be able to earn AAdvantage miles or
JetBlue points, respectively, when they fly only on American and JetBlue cooperative interline
routes. Under the terms of the agreements for commercial collaboration, American intends to
transfer eight slot pairs at Ronald Reagan National Airport in Washington D.C. (currently owned by
American) and one slot pair at White Plains, New York (currently owned by AMR Eagle) to JetBlue,
and JetBlue intends to transfer twelve slot pairs at JFK to American beginning in the fourth
quarter of 2010.
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The Company currently estimates that the implementation of its cornerstone strategy, the
implementation of the Company&#146;s proposed JBAs with British Airways/Iberia and JAL, and various
other alliance and network activities will result in incremental revenues and cost savings of over
$500&nbsp;million per year. The Company expects that it will realize the majority of these incremental
revenues and cost savings in 2011, and the remainder by year end 2012. This estimate is based on a
number of assumptions that are inherently uncertain, and the Company&#146;s ability to realize these
benefits depends on various factors, some of which are beyond the Company&#146;s control, such as
obtaining regulatory approvals of its proposed JBAs and other factors referred to above in
&#147;Forward-Looking Information.&#148;
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The Company is in active labor contract negotiations with each of its organized labor groups. The
Company has negotiated tentative agreements with several workgroups within the TWU including the
Maintenance Control Technician group, the Material Logistics Specialists group and the Mechanic and
Related group. Agreements with these TWU groups are subject to ratification by the relevant
membership of TWU, and there are no assurances that these tentative agreements will be ratified.
These tentative agreements include lump sum payments and contractual salary increases. If these
contracts are ratified by union membership during the third quarter 2010, the Company will incur
approximately $60&nbsp;million for lump sum payments and contractual salary increases in that period.
Under these current tentative agreements, the Company anticipates productivity increases in future
quarters. Mediated negotiation continues with other TWU workgroups, the Allied Pilots Association
(APA)&nbsp;and the Association of Professional Flight Attendants (APFA).
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Based on analysis of airline industry labor contracts, the Company estimates that at the beginning
of 2010, American&#146;s labor cost disadvantage (the amount by which its labor costs exceed what such
costs would be if they were determined based on other network carrier labor contracts) was
approximately $600&nbsp;million per year. The Company expects this gap to narrow as open industry labor
contracts are settled. This expectation is based on a number of assumptions, the validity of which
cannot be assured. The airline industry labor contract negotiation process is inherently uncertain
and the results of labor contract negotiations are difficult to predict.
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In March of 2010, the President signed into law comprehensive health care reform legislation under
the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (HR 3590) and the Health Care Education and
Affordability Reconciliation Act (HR 4872) (the Acts). The Acts contain provisions potentially
impacting the Company&#146;s cost and accounting for active employee and retiree medical benefits in
future periods. However, according to the recently released interim final regulations promulgated
under the Acts, the Company&#146;s retiree medical benefits will be exempt from many of the mandates of
the Acts under a grandfathering provision. Thus, under the Company&#146;s current assessment of the
cost and accounting implications of the Acts, no significant impact to its financial statements is
expected.
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In June&nbsp;2010, AMR reiterated its intent to evaluate the possible divestiture of AMR Eagle, its
wholly-owned regional carrier. AMR Eagle owns two regional airlines
&#150; American Eagle Airlines,
Inc (American Eagle) and Executive Airlines, Inc. (Executive). American Eagle feeds American
Airlines hubs throughout North America, and its affiliate, Executive, carries the American Eagle
name throughout the Bahamas and the Caribbean from bases in Miami and San Juan, Puerto Rico. No
prediction can be made as to the outcome of any such evaluation, and if AMR were to decide to
pursue a divestiture of AMR Eagle, no prediction can be made as to whether any such divestiture
will be completed or the impact of any such divestiture on the Company.
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On July 21, 2010, President Obama signed into law the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer
Protection Act (The Dodd-Frank Act). The Dodd-Frank Act contains provisions which may impact the
Company, but those effects cannot be predicted at this time. For example, our fuel hedging
activities may be affected by the Act and regulations promulgated under the Act.
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->-12-<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif">




<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The Company&#146;s ability to become profitable and its ability to continue to fund its obligations on
an ongoing basis will depend on a number of factors, many of which are largely beyond the Company&#146;s
control. Certain risk factors that affect the Company&#146;s business and financial results are
discussed in the Risk Factors listed in Item&nbsp;1A in the 2009 Form 10-K. In addition, most of the
Company&#146;s largest domestic competitors and several smaller carriers have filed for bankruptcy in
previous years and have used this process to significantly reduce contractual labor and other
costs. In order to remain competitive and to improve its financial condition, the Company must
continue to take steps to generate additional revenues and to reduce its costs. Although the
Company has a number of initiatives underway to address its cost and revenue challenges, some of
these initiatives involve changes to the Company&#146;s business which it may be unable to implement. It
has also become increasingly difficult to identify and implement significant revenue enhancement
and cost savings initiatives. The adequacy and ultimate success of the Company&#146;s initiatives to
generate additional revenues and reduce costs cannot be assured. Moreover, whether the Company&#146;s
initiatives will be adequate or successful depends in large measure on factors beyond its control,
notably the overall industry environment, including passenger demand, yield and industry capacity
growth, and fuel prices. It will be very difficult for the Company to continue to fund its
obligations on an ongoing basis, and to return to profitability, if the overall industry revenue
environment does not improve substantially or if fuel prices were to persist at high levels for an
extended period.
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>LIQUIDITY AND CAPITAL RESOURCES</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><U><B>Significant Indebtedness and Future Financing </B></U>

</DIV>

<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The Company remains heavily indebted and has significant obligations (including substantial pension
funding obligations), as described more fully under Item&nbsp;7, &#147;Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis
of Financial Condition and Results of Operations&#148; in the Company&#146;s 2009 Form 10-K. Indebtedness is
a significant risk to the Company as discussed in the Risk Factors listed in Item&nbsp;1A in the 2009
Form 10-K. During the last few years, the Company raised substantial financing to fund capital
commitments (mainly for aircraft and ground properties), debt maturities, and employee pension
obligations, and to bolster its liquidity. To meet the Company&#146;s commitments, to maintain
sufficient liquidity and because the Company has significant debt, lease and other obligations in
the next several years, including commitments to purchase aircraft, as well as substantial pension
funding obligations (refer to Contractual Obligations in Item&nbsp;7, &#147;Management&#146;s Discussion and
Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations&#148; in the 2009 Form 10-K), the Company will
need access to substantial additional funding. An inability to obtain necessary additional funding
on acceptable terms would have a material adverse impact on the Company and on its ability to
sustain its operations.
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">As of June&nbsp;30, 2010, the Company is required to make scheduled principal payments of approximately
$517&nbsp;million on long-term debt and approximately $26&nbsp;million in payments on capital leases, and the
Company expects to spend approximately $1.0&nbsp;billion on capital expenditures, including aircraft
commitments, for the remainder of 2010. In addition, the global economic downturn, rising fuel
prices, the possibility of being required to post reserves under credit card processing agreements,
and the obligation to post cash collateral on fuel hedging contracts and fund pension plan
contributions, among other things, may in the future negatively impact the Company&#146;s liquidity.
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The Company&#146;s substantial indebtedness and other obligations have important consequences. For
example, they: (i)&nbsp;limit the Company&#146;s ability to obtain additional funding for working capital,
capital expenditures, acquisitions, investments and general corporate purposes, and adversely
affect the terms on which such funding could be obtained; (ii)&nbsp;require the Company to dedicate a
substantial portion of its cash flow from operations to payments on its indebtedness and other
obligations, thereby reducing the funds available for other purposes; (iii)&nbsp;make the Company more
vulnerable to economic downturns and catastrophic external events; and (iv)&nbsp;limit the Company&#146;s
ability to withstand competitive pressures and reduce its flexibility in responding to changing
business and economic conditions.
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->-13-<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif">




<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The Company&#146;s possible remaining financing sources primarily include: (i)&nbsp;a very limited amount of
additional secured aircraft debt or sale leaseback transactions involving owned aircraft; (ii)&nbsp;debt
secured by other assets; (iii)&nbsp;securitization of future operating receipts; (iv)&nbsp;the sale or
monetization of certain assets; (v)&nbsp;unsecured debt; and (vi)&nbsp;issuance of equity or equity-like
securities. Besides unencumbered aircraft, the Company&#146;s most likely sources of liquidity include
the financing of route authorities, takeoff and landing slots, spare parts, and the sale or
financing of certain of AMR&#146;s business units and subsidiaries, such as AMR Eagle. The Company&#146;s
ability to obtain future financing is limited by the value of its unencumbered assets. Almost all
of the Company&#146;s aircraft assets (including aircraft eligible for the benefits of Section&nbsp;1110 of
the U.S. Bankruptcy Code) are encumbered. Also, the market value of these aircraft assets has
declined in recent years, and may continue to decline. The Company believes it has approximately
$2&nbsp;billion in assets that could be used as possible financing sources as of the date of this
filing. However, many of these assets may be difficult to finance, and the availability and level
of the financing sources described above cannot be assured.
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">As of June&nbsp;30, 2010, American had 24 Boeing 737-800 aircraft purchase commitments for the remainder
of 2010 and eight Boeing 737-800 aircraft purchase commitments in 2011. In addition to these
aircraft purchase commitments, American had firm commitments for eleven Boeing 737-800 aircraft and
seven Boeing 777 aircraft scheduled to be delivered in 2013 through 2016. In addition, American
previously announced plans (subject to certain reconfirmation rights) to acquire 42 Boeing 787-9
aircraft, with the right to acquire an additional 58 Boeing 787-9 aircraft. American has selected
GE Aviation as the exclusive provider of engines for its expected order of Boeing 787-9 aircraft.
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">As of June&nbsp;30, 2010, payments for the above purchase commitments will approximate $658&nbsp;million in
the remainder of 2010, $348&nbsp;million in 2011, $217&nbsp;million in 2012, $463&nbsp;million in 2013, $224
million in 2014, and $246&nbsp;million for 2015 and beyond. These amounts are net of purchase deposits
currently held by the manufacturers.
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On July&nbsp;21, 2010, the Company entered into an amendment to Purchase Agreement No.&nbsp;1977 with the
Boeing Company to exercise rights to acquire additional Boeing 737-800 aircraft. Pursuant to the
amendment, American exercised rights to purchase 35 Boeing 737-800 aircraft for delivery in 2011
and 2012. The Company&#146;s total purchase commitments are expected to increase to approximately $4
billion at the end of the third quarter 2010, reflecting this transaction and aircraft deliveries
during that period. In conjunction with this transaction, American has arranged for backstop
financing of the additional Boeing 737-800 aircraft deliveries, subject to certain terms and
conditions.
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In 2008, the Company entered into a new purchase agreement with Boeing for the acquisition of 42
firm Boeing 787-9 aircraft and purchase rights to acquire up to 58 additional B787 aircraft. Per
the purchase agreement, the first such aircraft was scheduled to be delivered in 2012, and the last
firm aircraft was scheduled to be delivered in 2018 with deliveries of additional aircraft, if any,
scheduled between 2015 and 2020. In July&nbsp;2010, the Company and Boeing agreed upon a revised
delivery schedule due to the impact of the overall Boeing 787 program delay on American&#146;s delivery
positions. The first aircraft is currently scheduled to be delivered in 2014, and the last firm
aircraft is scheduled to be delivered in 2018 with deliveries of additional aircraft, if any,
scheduled between 2016 and 2021. Additionally, the revised delivery schedule includes terms and
conditions consistent with the original agreement and allows the Company the confirmation rights
described below.
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Under the current 787-9 purchase agreement, except as described below, American will not be
obligated to purchase a 787-9 aircraft unless it gives Boeing notice confirming its election to do
so at least 18&nbsp;months prior to the scheduled delivery date for that aircraft. If American does not
give that notice with respect to an aircraft, the aircraft will no longer be subject to the 787-9
purchase agreement. These confirmation rights may be exercised until a specified date, May&nbsp;1, 2014
under the current agreement, provided that those rights will terminate earlier if American reaches
a collective bargaining agreement with its pilots union that includes provisions enabling American
to utilize the 787-9 to American&#146;s satisfaction in the operations desired by American, or if
American confirms its election to purchase any of the initial 42 787-9 aircraft. While there can
be no assurances, American expects that it will have reached an agreement as described above with
its pilots union prior to the first notification date. In either of those events, American would
become obligated to purchase all of the initial 42 aircraft then subject to the purchase agreement.
If neither of those events occurs prior to May&nbsp;1, 2014 under the current agreement, then on that
date American may elect to purchase all of the initial 42 aircraft then subject to the purchase
agreement, and if it does not elect to do so, the purchase agreement will terminate in its
entirety.
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The Company&#146;s continued aircraft replacement strategy, and its execution of that strategy, will
depend on such factors as future economic and industry conditions and the financial condition of
the Company.
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->-14-<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif">




<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><U><B>Credit Card Processing and Other Reserves</B></U>
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">American has agreements with a number of credit card companies and processors to accept credit
cards for the sale of air travel and other services. Under certain of these agreements, the related
credit card processor may hold back a reserve from American&#146;s credit card receivables following the
occurrence of certain events, including the failure of American to maintain certain levels of
liquidity (as specified in each agreement).
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Under such agreements, the amount of the reserve that may be required generally is based on the
processor&#146;s exposure to the Company under the applicable agreement and, in the case a reserve is
required because of American&#146;s failure to maintain a certain level of liquidity, the amount of such
liquidity. As of June&nbsp;30, 2010, the Company was not required to maintain any reserve under such
agreements. If circumstances were to occur that would allow the credit card processor to require
the Company to maintain a reserve, the Company&#146;s liquidity would be negatively impacted.
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><U><B>Pension Funding Obligation</B></U>
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The Company is required to make minimum contributions to its defined benefit pension plans under
the minimum funding requirements of ERISA, the Pension Funding Equity Act of 2004 and the Pension
Protection Act of 2006. On June&nbsp;25, 2010, President Obama signed the Preservation of Access to Care
for Medical Beneficiaries and Pension Relief Act of 2010 (the Relief Act), H.R. 3962, into law.
The Relief Act provides for temporary, targeted funding relief (subject to certain terms and
conditions) for single employer and multiemployer pension plans that suffered significant losses in
asset value due to the steep market slide in 2008. Under the Relief Act, the Company&#146;s 2010
minimum contributions to its defined benefit pension plans have been reduced from $525&nbsp;million to
approximately $460&nbsp;million. On July&nbsp;15, 2010, the Company contributed an additional $72&nbsp;million to
its defined benefit pension plans, for a total of $144&nbsp;million in 2010 as of the date of this
filing.
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><U><B>Cash Flow Activity</B></U>
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">At June&nbsp;30, 2010, the Company had $5.1&nbsp;billion in unrestricted cash and short-term investments,
which is a $684&nbsp;million increase from the balance as of December&nbsp;31, 2009. Net cash provided by
operating activities in the six-month period ended June&nbsp;30, 2010 was $1.1&nbsp;billion, which was
comparable to $828&nbsp;million over the same period in 2009 which reflects an improved operating
environment in 2010.
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The Company made scheduled debt and capital lease payments of $351&nbsp;million and invested $670
million in capital expenditures in the first six months of 2010. Capital expenditures primarily
consisted of new aircraft and certain aircraft modifications.
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The Company also continued to enter into previously arranged debt and sale leasebacks upon the
delivery of new aircraft in the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2010. In the first and second quarters
of 2010, American received delivery of 21 new aircraft financed through $687&nbsp;million of various
previously announced arrangements.
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In the past, the Company has from time to time refinanced, redeemed or repurchased its debt and
taken other steps to reduce its debt or lease obligations or otherwise improve its balance sheet.
Going forward, depending on market conditions, its cash positions and other considerations, the
Company may continue to take such actions.
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><U><B>War-Risk Insurance</B></U>
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The U.S. government has agreed to provide commercial war-risk insurance for U.S. based airlines
through August&nbsp;31, 2010, covering losses to employees, passengers, third parties and aircraft. If
the U.S. government were to cease providing such insurance in whole or in part, it is likely that
the Company could obtain comparable coverage in the commercial market, but the Company would incur
substantially higher premiums and more restrictive terms. There can be no assurance that
comparable war-risk coverage will be available in the commercial market. If the Company is unable
to obtain adequate war-risk coverage at commercially reasonable rates, the Company would be
adversely affected.
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->-15-<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif">




<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><U><B>For the Six Months Ended June&nbsp;30, 2010 and 2009</B></U>

</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><FONT style="FONT-variant: SMALL-CAPS"><B>Revenues</B></FONT>

</DIV>

<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The Company&#146;s revenues increased approximately $1.0&nbsp;billion, or 10.4&nbsp;percent, to $10.7&nbsp;billion in
the first six months of 2010 from the same period last year. American&#146;s passenger revenues
increased by 10.2&nbsp;percent, or $753&nbsp;million, on a 1.4&nbsp;percent decrease in capacity (available seat
mile) (ASM). American&#146;s passenger load factor increased 2.1 points to 80.9&nbsp;percent while passenger
yield increased by 8.9&nbsp;percent to 13.31 cents. This resulted in an increase in passenger revenue
per available seat mile (RASM)&nbsp;of 11.8&nbsp;percent to 10.78 cents. Following is additional information
regarding American&#146;s domestic and international RASM and capacity:
</DIV>

</TABLE>
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The Company&#146;s Regional Affiliates include two wholly owned subsidiaries, American Eagle Airlines,
Inc. and Executive Airlines, Inc. (collectively, AMR Eagle), and an independent carrier with which
American has a capacity purchase agreement, Chautauqua Airlines, Inc. (Chautauqua).
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Regional Affiliates&#146; passenger revenues, which are based on industry standard proration agreements
for flights connecting to American flights, increased $128&nbsp;million, or 13.2&nbsp;percent, to $1.1
billion as a result of higher yield. Regional Affiliates&#146; traffic increased 1.2&nbsp;percent to 4.1
billion revenue passenger miles (RPMs), on a capacity increase of approximately one-half of a
percent to 5.8&nbsp;billion ASMs, resulting in a one-half point increase in the passenger load factor to
71.0&nbsp;percent.
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Other revenues increased 7.7&nbsp;percent, or $86&nbsp;million, to $1.2&nbsp;billion due to increases in baggage
and AAdvantage partner revenues.
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->-16-<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>

<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif">




<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><FONT style="FONT-variant: SMALL-CAPS"><B>Operating Expenses</B></FONT>
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The Company&#146;s total operating expenses increased 6.8&nbsp;percent, or $689&nbsp;million, to $10.9&nbsp;billion in
the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2010 compared to the same period in 2009. The Company&#146;s operating
expenses per ASM in the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2010 increased 8.2&nbsp;percent to 12.76 cents
compared to the same period of 2009. These increases are due primarily to increased fuel prices in
the first half of 2010 compared to the first half of 2009.
</DIV>

<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">

    <TD><DIV style="text-align: justify">Aircraft fuel expense increased primarily due to a 21.0&nbsp;percent increase in the
Company&#146;s price per gallon of fuel (net of the impact of fuel hedging). The Company
recorded $103&nbsp;million and $422&nbsp;million in net losses on its fuel hedging contracts for
the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2010 and June&nbsp;30, 2009, respectively.</DIV></TD>
</TR>

<TR style="font-size: 3pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="left">(b)</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD><DIV style="text-align: justify">Regional payments to AMR Eagle expense increased in conjunction with the 13.2
percent increase in Regional Affiliates&#146; passenger revenue.</DIV></TD>
</TR>

<TR style="font-size: 3pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="left">(c)</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD><DIV style="text-align: justify">Maintenance, materials and repairs increased due to the timing of materials and
repairs expenses.</DIV></TD>
</TR>

<TR style="font-size: 3pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="left">(d)</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD><DIV style="text-align: justify">Commissions, booking fees and credit card expense increased 13.7&nbsp;percent primarily
in conjunction with the 10.4&nbsp;percent increase in the Company&#146;s revenues.</DIV></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>



<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><FONT style="FONT-variant: SMALL-CAPS"><B>Other Income (Expense)</B></FONT>
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Interest income decreased $9&nbsp;million due to a decrease in interest rates. Interest expense
increased $63&nbsp;million as a result of an increase in the Company&#146;s long-term debt balance.
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><FONT style="FONT-variant: SMALL-CAPS"><B>Income Tax </B></FONT>
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The
Company did not record a net tax provision (benefit)&nbsp;associated
with its net loss for the six months ended June 30, 2010 or June 30,
2009 due to the Company providing a valuation allowance, as discussed in Note 4 to the
condensed consolidated financial statements.
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->-17-<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>
